advice: Your medicine will not be enough for the child.
Try to get the child with a danger sign to a health facility as soon as possible.
Advise to give fluids and continue feeding.
If the child can drink and feed, continue to offer fluids and food on the way to the health facility.
If the child is still breastfeeding, continue breastfeeding. Offer the breast more frequently and for a longer time at each feed.
If the child is not breastfeeding, offer water to drink and some easy-to-eat food.
If the child has diarrhoea, start giving ORS solution right away. Sometimes the ORS solution can help the child stop vomiting so the child can take other oral medicines.

To keep the child warm, cover the child, including head, hands, and feet with a blanket. Keep the child dry if it rains. If the weather is cold, put a cap on the child’s head and hold the child close to her body.
If the child is hot with fever, avoid covering too much. A light cloth or blanket may be enough if the weather is warm. If the body becomes very hot, remove even the light blanket.
